metadata.title: Kilopascals (kPa) to Pounds per Square Inch (psi) — Pressure Converter
metadata.description: Convert pressure values between kilopascals (kPa) and pounds per square inch (psi). Includes clear formula, worked examples, guidance on gauge vs absolute pressure, measurement accuracy considerations, and authoritative citations.

introduction: This tool converts pressure values expressed in kilopascals (kPa) to pounds per square inch (psi). Use it when you need a reliable numeric conversion between SI-derived pressure units and common imperial units used in automotive, HVAC, and industrial contexts.

The calculator assumes numeric input is a pressure value in kilopascals. It does not infer whether the value is gauge or absolute pressure; confirm the measurement reference (gauge vs absolute) before converting for safety-critical or regulatory applications.
methodology: This conversion uses a fixed multiplicative relationship between the two unit systems. No empirical calibration factors or sensor-specific corrections are applied by the converter.

For measurement and reporting that require traceability or compliance, follow recommended practices for instrument calibration and uncertainty reporting as described by NIST and ISO standards referenced below.
how_is_calculated: Steps: 1) Confirm your input kPa value represents the correct reference (gauge or absolute). 2) Multiply the kPa value by 0.14503773773 to obtain psi. 3) Round the result according to required significant figures or measurement uncertainty.

faqs.question: Is the conversion factor exact?
faqs.answer: The conversion is a fixed mathematical relationship based on defined SI and imperial unit definitions. The numeric factor shown is sufficient for typical engineering and everyday use. For laboratory-grade reporting include measurement uncertainty and instrument traceability per NIST and ISO guidance.

faqs.question: How do I handle gauge versus absolute pressure?
faqs.answer: Kilopascal readings may be gauge (relative to ambient) or absolute (relative to vacuum). This converter treats the numeric input as whatever the instrument reports. To convert between gauge and absolute, add or subtract local atmospheric pressure (approximately 101.325 kPa at sea level) before converting if needed.

faqs.question: What rounding or precision should I use?
faqs.answer: Select rounding based on the measuring device's accuracy and the required uncertainty reporting. For example, tire pressure is commonly reported to one decimal place in psi; laboratory work may require more significant figures and an uncertainty statement conforming to ISO 17025.

faqs.question: Can I use this for safety-critical calculations?
faqs.answer: This converter provides the numeric unit conversion only. For safety-critical applications verify instrument calibration, measurement conditions, and applicable regulatory requirements. Follow calibration and competence standards such as ISO 17025 and ISO 10012, and any industry-specific OSHA guidance.

faqs.question: Why do I sometimes see pressure given in bar or Pa?
faqs.answer: Bar and pascal (Pa) are common metric pressure units. 1 bar = 100 kPa. The pascal is the SI base unit of pressure (1 kPa = 1000 Pa). Convert between these as intermediate steps if required.

glossary.definition: A metric unit of pressure equal to 1,000 pascals. Common in engineering and weather reporting.
An imperial unit of pressure equal to one pound-force applied to an area of one square inch.
Pressure measured relative to ambient (local atmospheric) pressure.
Pressure measured relative to a perfect vacuum. Absolute pressure = gauge pressure + atmospheric pressure.
A quantitative indication of the dispersion of values that could reasonably be attributed to the measured quantity; reportable per ISO and NIST guidance.

citations.label: NIST Special Publication 811, Guide for the Use of the International System of Units (SI)
ISO/IEC 17025: General requirements for the competence of testing and calibration laboratories
ISO 10012: Measurement management systems — Requirements for measurement processes and measuring equipment
IEEE Standards on sensor and transducer interfaces (relevant for measurement systems)
Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) — workplace safety resources

summary: Multiply kPa by 0.14503773773 to get psi, or divide by 6.894757293168 to go the other way.

Confirm whether your input is gauge or absolute pressure before converting for applications where reference matters, and follow calibration and uncertainty reporting standards for regulated or safety-critical work.
